subject: ARTS
text: Without the knowledge of dance (nrityashastra) the principles of _ sculpture (Shilpashatra) are very difficult to understand.

subject: ARTS
text: NOTE TO THE TEACHERS

subject: ARTS
text: Teachers may provide a spacious hall with sufficient space for children to move and dance. The space should have ample ventilation and adequate lights. Guide the children according to their ability to adopt the given principles. Help them to form groups and work as a team.

subject: ARTS
text: PEDAGOGICAL PRINCIPLES

subject: ARTS
text: 1. Help children understand body movements in relation to geometrical shapes to try out comfortable and challenging postures.

subject: ARTS
text: 2. Interrelationship of arts with sculpture, particularly with body and geometrical shapes.

subject: ARTS
text: 3. Understanding some basic units of dance with a focus on feet movement and rhythm, and exploring mathematical permutations and combinations of talas.

subject: ARTS
text: 4. Introduction to jumps and pirouettes in dance, and making them comfortable to practice various jumps. This will be physically beneficial for the children.

subject: ARTS
text: 5. Expression of emotions—encourage children to express their emotions, both positive and negative to foster emotional well-being.

subject: ARTS
text: kbd bese a

subject: ARTS
text: 6. Using hand gestures as a communication medium.

subject: ARTS
text: 7. Learn about dance forms of India including, classical and traditional forms, thereby understanding the cultural diversity of India.

subject: ARTS
text: 8. Gender sensitisation with learning and understanding role-play irrespective of gender, especially in the case of traditional dances.

subject: ARTS
text: 9. Introduction to contemporary Indian dance and use of dance in popular culture. Exploring creativity with movements.

subject: ARTS
text: 10. Learning and researching notable Indian dance personalities.

subject: ARTS
text: 11. Importance of teamwork and collaborative effort in producing dance.

subject: ARTS
text: 12. Holistic appreciation of dance and movement with due importance to nature.

subject: ARTS
text: THE CURRICULAR GOALS AND COMPETENCIES ARE GIVEN BELOW

subject: ARTS
text: CG-1: Develops openness to explore and express themselves through various art forms.

subject: ARTS
text: C-1.1: Confidently expresses their personal and everyday life experiences through a variety of dance and movement activities.

subject: ARTS
text: C-1.2: Demonstrates flexibility in the process of collaboratively developing dance and movement practices.

subject: ARTS
text: CG-2: Applies their imagination and creativity to explore alternative ideas through the Arts.

subject: ARTS
text: C-2.1: Creates and performs dance and movement sequences that challenge stereotypes observed in their surroundings (such as gender roles).

subject: ARTS
text: C-2.2: Connects elements of dance and movement, mudras, gestures and postures with personal experiences, emotions, and imaginations.

subject: ARTS
text: CG-3: Understands and applies artistic elements, processes, and techniques.

subject: ARTS
text: C-3.1: Demonstrates stage etiquette, care for stage equipment, props and costumes; and makes informed choice while using dance and movement techniques.

subject: ARTS
text: C-3.2: Reworks ideas and expressions used in dance and movement from the stage of planning to final performance, and reviews the entire process.

subject: ARTS
text: CG-4: Acquaints themselves with a range of aesthetic sensibilities in regional Arts and cultural practices.

subject: ARTS
text: C-4.1: Demonstrates familiarity with various local, and regional forms of dance and movement.

subject: ARTS
text: C-4.2: Describes the life and work of a few local dancers, and movement artists in their region and across the India.

subject: ARTS
text: DANCING BODY IN SCULPTURES

subject: ARTS
text: > The Vishnudharmottara Purana emphasises the interrelation and interdependence between various art forms.

subject: ARTS
text: Dated around 400 to 600 CE, the end of the Gupta period, is also known as the golden age of Indian arts. It understands the importance of spatial concepts of the performing body.

subject: ARTS
text: In this text, a discussion occurs between King Vajra and Markandeya on painting and drama in a memorable verse. It states the manifold interrelationship of performing and visual art.

subject: ARTS
text: Sage Markandeya instructs, “One who does not know the laws of painting (chitra) can never understand the laws of image-making (shilpa); and, it is difficult to understand the laws of painting (chitra) without any knowledge of the technique of dancing (nrtya)...”.

subject: ARTS
text: The precision of geometrical shapes in dance and sculptures was probably worked out due to this interdisciplinary understanding.

subject: ARTS
text: IN HOW MANY WAYS CAN YOU JUMP AND SPIN IN DANCE?

subject: ARTS
text: Jumps, utplavana, pirouettes and bhramaris (spins) play animportant role in a dance performance. The execution of jumps and pirouettes is another unit of dance vocabulary, which can be used in pure dance or to enhance emotive content.

subject: ARTS
text: Both jumps and pirouettes can be performed in rhythm with music beats, enhancing the overall impact of a dance. In a dance with stories, it can be without rhythm.

subject: ARTS

subject: ARTS
text: These movements are an integral part of our folk, traditional and classical dance forms. In Karnataka’s Yakshagana, the artist performs pirouettes while standing on knees, often executing them multiple times. subject: ARTS
text: BEYOND BOUNDARIES

subject: ARTS
text: In Kriti, Grade 6, we discussed many dance traditions and the role of male and female dancers. In solo traditions, the solo dancer plays different roles and switches from one character to another. There was a strong tradition of female dancers all over India, who enacted stories and poetries, taking on various roles. Simultaneously, there were male dancers who sometimes performed in the garb of a woman. One such personality is the famous Kuchipudi dancer, Vedantam Satyanarayana Sarma, who performed in female costume.

subject: ARTS
text: f

subject: ARTS
text: Vedantam Satyanarayana Sarma

subject: ARTS
text: In traditional dance-drama traditions male dancers often take on the role of women and their costume decides the portrayal of the character. Some dance traditions also use masks for portrayals like Chhau which we learnt about in Kriti, Grade 6.

subject: ARTS
text: We will learn about two more such performance traditions where men have traditionally been playing female characters. Though now both traditions are welcoming women into their traditional practises.

subject: ARTS
text: BHAGAVATA MELA NATAKAM FROM MELATTUR, TAMIL NADU

subject: ARTS
text: A dance-drama tradition of southern India. This form to originated in the village of Kuchipudi in Andhra Pradesh, the main protagonists were Tirtha Narayana Yati and Siddhendra

subject: ARTS
text: Yogi. Some bhagavatars moved from Andhra after the N. Sreekanth decline of the Vijayanagara Natarajan

subject: ARTS
text: Empire to Melattur, Thanjavur

subject: ARTS
text: patronised by the Nayaka kings and thus started the Melattur tradition. Famous Sanskrit scholars, Gopal Krishna Shastri and his son Venkatrama Shastri became disciples ofsaint Narayana Tirtha Yati. Patrons, Achyutappa Nayak and Sevappa Nayak gifted the village Mellatur to these Brahmans and it became a centre of fine arts. Early 20th century CE, the most famous bhagavatar was Natesha Iyer, and after his death, the troupe was continued under G. Swaminathan. Other important persons were Balu Bhagavathar and T.V. Natesh Bhagavathar. E. Krishna Iyer was instrumental in reviving the tradition with the Madras Music Academy in 1950.

subject: ARTS
text: The main performance was Prahlada Charitam at the Varadaraja Perumal temple during Narasimha Jayanti in May or June. Conventionally male dancers play the role of women.

subject: ARTS
text: Indian cinema throughout its existence has used many Indian dances in its choreography. Notable ones being Mughal-e-Azam, choreographed by Lacchu Maharaj and jhanak jhanak payal baje by Gopi Krishna. Many south Indian actresses were accomplished Bharatanatyam dancers and danced beautifully in movies. Bharat Ratna awarded, M S Subbulakshmi had a flair for abhinaya and performed such sequences in many of her films. In recent times, the famous kahe ched ched mohe choreography by Birju§ Maharaj became very popular. Beautiful Garba sequences and many other folk forms are also seen in many movies in every part of the country.

subject: ARTS
text: 13 | PERSONALITIES

subject: ARTS
text: SHAMBHU MAHARAJ

subject: ARTS
text: Scion of the Lucknow Gharana of Kathak, Shambhu Maharaj belongs to a family of traditional Kathak dancers. His forefathers were gurus and dancers at the court of Nawab Wajid Ali Shah of Awadh. His father was the famous Kalka Prasad and uncle Binda Deen, who consolidated the Lucknow Gharana of Kathak. Trained under his uncle Binda Deen. Later, he established a post-independence with his elder brother Acchan Maharaj repetorrie of dance. He made his debut in Lucknow in 1926 at the All India Music Conference after which he performed regularly as a soloist, and with his elder brothers Acchan and Lacchu Maharaj. He moved to Delhi in 1955 and taught Kathak at the Shriram Bharatiya Kala Kendra, establishing the tradition of the Lucknow Gharana in Delhi. He was very famous for his abhinaya and bhav batana, and he performed such in the court style of sitting and enacting. He taught his nephew, the famous Birju Maharaj and many other famous Kathak dancers of India. He is survived by his sons Ram Mohan and Kishan Mohan who are also accomplished dancers, and gurus. He was the recipient of the Padma Shri in 1958 and Sangeet “~ Natak Academy Award in 1967. Birju Maharaj

subject: ARTS

subject: ARTS
text: KEDAR NATH SAHU

subject: ARTS
text: Kedar Nath Sahu was one of the leading exponents of Seraikella Chhau. He comes from a traditional family of Chhau dancers belonging to the Kanasari caste, who are engaged in these dance practices along with their main occupation of making household utensils. He started learning the dance form at a very early age from his father and grandfather. The dance form followed a Guru-Sishya Parampara and the art was orally transmitted from generation to generation. He performed in the troupe of Kumar Bijoy Pratap Singh Deo but later formed his own troupe with his disciples. Recipient of the Sangeet Natak Academy Award in 1981 and the Padma Shri in 2005. His performances received acclaim both in India and around the world. Many illustrious dancers trained under him as his students; the notable ones being Shashadhar Acharya, Gopal Prasad Dubey and Sharon Lowen to name a few.

subject: ARTS
text: NATYA

subject: ARTS
text: Natya is storytelling through performance. You have read the description of this earlier in the book and read about two natya

subject: ARTS
text: In this chapter, you will explore how dance elements can be

subject: ARTS
text: One lazy afternoon, Grandma gathered the children to tell them the story of Krishna and the snake Kaliya. She began her story in a soft animated voice bringing the story alive with her dramatic narration.

subject: ARTS
text: “Long ago, on the banks of the river Kalindi, there lived a monstrous serpent called Kaliya Naag. He was a terrible creature, hissing and_ coiling, frightening everyone who came near him. Even birds would not fly over the river, and children were too scared to play by its banks. But one day, little Krishna arrived.”

subject: ARTS
text: “Now, Krishna was not afraid of anything. He saw the frightened children and decided to help them. He climbed the tallest tree by the river, flute in hand, and began to play it. The music was so sweet and enchanting that it flowed over the water like sunlight on ripples. Even Kaliya couldn’t resist. The great serpent rose from the river, swaying to the melody, his anger forgotten and his eyes shut in joy. Then, Krishna leapt onto Kaliya’s hood and began to dance. Oh, how he danced! His tender feet moved nimbly with such grace and rhythm that even Kaliya, fierce as he was, couldn’t help but join in. Soon, birds were

subject: ARTS
text: 144 | KRITI

subject: ARTS
text: singing again, animals came out of hiding, and the children clapped and cheered. Kaliya calmed down and happily, slipped away into the river, never to trouble anyone again.”

subject: ARTS
text: The children listened with rapt attention and then excitedly asked grandma to help them enact this natya.

subject: ARTS
text: She replied, “Yes we have to plan and design the whole story, choreograph it with dance, music, enactment, costumes and stage design. You see children, through music and dance, even the wildest heart can be calmed. Natya—our beautiful art of storytelling —isn’t just for entertainment. It teaches, it heals, and it brings peace”.

subject: ARTS
text: All traditional performances begin with a salutation to seek blessings of the Almighty. Here you will see references of salutation and benediction with reference to natya.

subject: ARTS
text: She said, “In our traditions, every play begins and ends with gratitude. Before the performance, we seek blessings for its success—just as we start our day with a prayer or sing during the morning assembly at school. It helps us focus our mind and brings a sense of calm. The salutation is an essential part of any play’s preliminaries in the Indian natya tradition. Let us learn some prayers which can be recited as a salutation to the almighty and as benediction after the conclusion of the natya”.

subject: ARTS
text: NOTE TO THE TEACHERS

subject: ARTS
text: VISUAL ARTS PEDAGOGY WOULD NEED TO 1.

subject: ARTS
text: Dear Teacher,

subject: ARTS
text: Let us take our students deeper into the fascinating world of visual arts, ideas and communication. In this grade, the focusis on broadening their exposure to visual art processes and traditions while honing their skills and techniques. It is important that you read every chapter carefully. You can modify the activities to suit your local context and the specific needs of your students.

subject: ARTS
text: To create the best learning experience for every student consider the following points.

subject: ARTS
text: The Visual Arts classroom requires

subject: ARTS
text: Ample space for students to work comfortably. Sufficient light and ventilation. Organised storage and easy access to art materials, tools, basic stationery and audio-visual facilities.

subject: ARTS
text: 4. Space for showcasing and exhibiting artwork periodically.

subject: ARTS
text: Use storytelling and everyday examples to introduce concepts and processes.

subject: ARTS
text: Encourage students to freely express their original ideas, imaginations, emotions and curiosities in their artwork.

subject: ARTS
text: Encourage students to create original artwork inspired by their observations of everyday life and experiences, rather than copying images from other sources.

subject: ARTS
text: Allow students to explore, investigate, experiment, collaborate and have dialogues in the classroom. Include outdoor activities and field trips to explore and observe the life and culture around them. Organise visits to museums, heritage monuments and melas.

subject: ARTS
text: Invite local artists and craftspeople for interactive sessions, workshops for hands-on experience. Inculcate simple habits of cleaning up after working, putting back used materials and maintain art materials with care.

subject: ARTS
text: Encourage students’ participation and decision- making in selecting artwork for classroom display or exhibitions.

subject: ARTS
text: Visual arts, assessment should be based on the following Competencies for the Middle Stage.

subject: ARTS
text: CG

subject: ARTS
text: Expresses confidently their personal and everyday life experiences through various visual art forms. Demonstrates flexibility in the process of collaboratively developing visual arts practice. Creates visual artwork based on situations or stories that challenge stereotypes observed in their surroundings (such as gender roles).

subject: ARTS
text: Connects visual imagery, symbols, and visual metaphors with personal experiences, emotions, and imaginations.

subject: ARTS
text: C-3.1 Demonstrates care and makes informed choices, while using various materials, tools and techniques in the Visual Arts.

subject: ARTS
text: C-3.2 Refines ideas and techniques of visual expression from the stage of planning to the final presentation, and reviews the entire process.

subject: ARTS
text: c-4.1 Demonstrates familiarity with various local and regional forms of art.

subject: ARTS
text: C-4.2 Describes the life and work of a few local artists in their region and across India.

subject: ARTS
text: LEARNING OUTCOMES THAT CAN BE ASSESSED ACROSS CHAPTERS

subject: ARTS
text: C Learning Outcomes 1.1 | Exhibits artworks and confidently shares ideas, feelings and processes 1.2 | Tries new ideas and takes suggestions while collaborating with each other 3.1 | Carefully uses, cleans and stores art materials in an organised way A Discusses the scale, appearance, material and themes seen in artwork (e.g., sculptures/paintings seen in local art forms and heritage monuments) 4.2 | Uses art terminology while discussing or writing about artwork 4.2 | Enquires about the work and socio-economic conditions of local artists

subject: ARTS
text: Visuals help us communicate with one another. Examine the visuals on this page. Each one gives you information quickly and directly. Such visuals are called icons.

subject: ARTS
text: An icon is a simplified visual representation of an object, place or idea. Icons do not show too many details. For example, a mobile phone display has icons depicting the clock, remaining battery charge, network connections, applications, and so on. Below are a few other icons that you come across regularly.

subject: ARTS
text: Draw your object and make it appear three- dimensional using these two shading techniques:

subject: ARTS
text: 1. Cross-hatching is a shading technique that uses criss-cross lines.

subject: ARTS
text: Closely overlap lines in different directions to create darker tones.

subject: ARTS
text: Loosely overlap lines to create lighter tones.

subject: ARTS
text: Stippling

subject: ARTS
text: 2. Stippling is a shading technique that uses dots.

subject: ARTS
text: Place the dots close to one another to create darker tones.

subject: ARTS
text: Increase the space between dots to create lighter tones.

subject: ARTS
text: Use a separate sheet of A5 paper for each technique.

text: MAKE AN ICON OF YOUR OBJECT

subject: ARTS
text: Gather your drawings—the contour, silhouettes, cross-hatching and stippling. Which of these will you use to make an icon?

subject: ARTS
text: Remember that an icon is a simplified image. But it also needs to be identified quickly. It should, therefore, contain clear shapes and have only important details. Sometimes the silhouette of the object can be the icon.

subject: ARTS

subject: ARTS
text: It takes practice and keen observation to be able to make good icons. If you had to use your icon to communicate information, what would it be?

subject: ARTS
text: Signage informs us where a space is and what it is used for. In this activity, you will create signages using icons of objects for your school.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 1: Choose a space in your school such as the entrance, washrooms, play area, a space for eating meals, library, a space to keep your bags, shoes, and so on.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 2: Make a list of the objects that come to your mind when you think of this space.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 3: Choose the most important object in this space. For example, the door in an exit signage signifies its importance. If you have chosen two objects, try different ways of combining them to create one icon. For example, signage for a dining area can have a spoon and a fork; signage for an art room can have a palette and a brush.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 4: Remember that an icon is a simplified drawing that represents the object. *» Experiment with contours and sihouettes.

subject: ARTS
text: » Add only those details that characterise the object. Use only one colour.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 5: Create the icon in two or more ways.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 6: Choose the icon that expresses your purpose best and can be used as a signage for the chosen space. Create this icon on an A5 sheet.

subject: ARTS
text: Show the signage to your friends and ask them what they think about it.

subject: ARTS
text: Note: Think of the objects that you use regularly while creating icons. For example, you may not use a fork and spoon when you eat. So can you think of alternative icons to represent your food?

subject: ARTS
text: Colours are visible because of light. When light changes, the appearance of colours also changes. A bright red tomato may look dull and dark ina dimly lit room. When there is too much light, everything appears white. When there is no light, everything appears black. In visual art, such effects of light are shown by creating tints, shades and tones of colour.

subject: ARTS
text: Colour is an important element of visual art. With regular practice, you will improve your techniques of making, mixing and working with colours. You will learn to use the colour wheel not only for your work, but also to appreciate other artworks.

subject: ARTS
text: Not all people see colours the same way. It is important to be sensitive to how each person sees colour. Those who have colour vision impairment, commonly called colour blindness, see a few colours differently. Red may appear brown or they may find it difficult to differentiate between blue and green. There are many visual artists and designers with vision impairment of various kinds. They have excelled in their careers by finding creative solutions to work with their impairments.

subject: ARTS
text: Plants change form and colour as they grow through different seasons. Fruits and vegetables are often green when they are raw and change colours as they ripen. Let us create artistic studies of plants to understand colours better.

subject: ARTS
text: STUDY A PLANT THROUGH DRAWING

subject: ARTS
text: Step 1: Select a stem with a few leaves ora single flower (in any stage of its life).

subject: ARTS
text: Step 2: Place it in front of you and do not disturb its position.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 3: Sit at least two feet away and observe its shapes and the space around it.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 4: Using light lines, make quick drawings from two different angles.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 5: Next, choose one of the angles that you tried and start another drawing.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 6: Cover the maximum space on your paper and draw slowly to capture the details.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 7: Complete the drawing and keep it ready to start colouring.

subject: ARTS
text: Miniature paintings are of many styles and are generally small in size. In India, these were initially done on palm leaves. From the 12th century CE, artists began to use paper as the base for miniature paintings. Their themes included religious texts, mythology, nature, portraiture and court life.

subject: ARTS
text: Mughal miniature Kishangarh miniature

subject: ARTS
text: The word ‘miniature’ originates from 'minium’, a red-coloured

subject: ARTS
text: pigment that was used to draw outlines and write text in medieval manuscripts.

subject: ARTS
text: The table below tells you about the source of some of the colours used in miniatures. These were processed and mixed with gum extracted from the Babul tree to act as a binder.

subject: ARTS
text: COLOUR | SOURCE

subject: ARTS
text: Bright red Sindhoor or vermillion

subject: ARTS
text: Earthy red Geru or red clay

subject: ARTS

subject: ARTS
text: Malachite (copper carbonate)

subject: ARTS
text: Lapis lazuli/Indigo

subject: ARTS
text: Carbon

subject: ARTS
text: Khariya or white clay

subject: ARTS
text: Gold and silver were also used in miniature paintings. Gold and silver are hammered into very thin sheets known as gold leaf and silver leaf. These are used in paintings and other crafts.

subject: ARTS

text: They used brushes made of soft hair from the fur or hair of animals such as camels, goats, cows, and hair from the tails of rats, squirrels and mongoose.

subject: ARTS
text: It is important to take care of the space we work in, as well as the materials and tools we use for artwork.

subject: ARTS
text: Always clean your brushes, palettes and other tools thoroughly with soap after every use. Close paint tubes, bottles, sketch pens and markers with their caps, to prevent colour from drying.

subject: ARTS
text: Store all materials in an organised way so that they can be easily found and used by others too.

subject: ARTS
text: Imagine you have entered a time machine and have been transported to 8th century CE. You find yourself in front of this massive rock-cut temple sculpture at Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu.

subject: ARTS
text: You see the sculptors at work. They tell you that they are carving the ‘Descent of Ganga’. Some others tell you the story of ‘Arjuna’s Penance’.

subject: ARTS
text: As you watch them work, you imagine the river flows down the cleft between the two boulders and all life gathering around the river. The sculpture brings alive the stories and myths celebrating life around water. Although some figures can be seen very clearly, others look unfinished. Each scene draws you in and you see more.

text: The curtain continued to speak and told them the story of how it was made.

subject: ARTS
text: “When your passed away, your parents kept few of the special clothes she used to wear. I am the patchwork they created using pieces of fabric from her clothes.

subject: ARTS
text: Look at all the pieces that have been stitched together on my body. Each of these is from the clothes your Aaji wore. Here is a piece from the beautiful sweater she knitted herself. Next to it, is a piece from the yellow saree that had a big tea stain! Touch the design on it, your father took that stained portion and

subject: ARTS
text: Aaji

subject: ARTS
text: created this beautiful embroidery over it. Do you see the square window at the centre of this patchwork? It was made by a process called crochet. This piece was your Aaqji's favourite. Have you noticed the bottom edge of the patchwork? These are called tassels. You will see fine threads in it, arranged together and knotted in beautiful patterns. There are some loose threads even in my tear ...see? You can clearly see the warp and weft of the weave.

subject: ARTS
text: Remember, I am not just a curtain, lama patchwork of stories. Each piece in me has its own story. They are all stitched together with many threads.

subject: ARTS
text: When threads start fighting among themselves like you both just did, what do you think will happen?”

subject: ARTS
text: Dhaaga and Soodi looked at each other and smiled, “Shall we repair the tear together?”, Soodi asked Dhaaga. He agreed and they got busy. What would you do if you were Dhaaga or Soodi?

subject: ARTS
text: Calligraphy is much more than the art of writing letters to spell words. Artists pour emotions into each letter to create a variety of expressions. They spend a lot of time and effort in writing, inscribing and carving by hand. Each letter style has a purpose. In ancient manuscripts, letters were decorative and flowed with life. Some letters were creatively placed to look like a frame or picture. Today’s newspapers use bold and clear letters to draw our attention and help readers read information quickly.

subject: ARTS
text: The materials and tools used in calligraphy include a variety of quills, brushes, nibs, inks and paints on surfaces like palm leaf, cloth, paper, and so on.

text: Which letters can you find in the Indian Rupee symbol? The symbol of the Indian rupee is derived from the letter ¥ from the word Rupiah in the Devanagari script. The top horizontal line also known as the Shiro-Rekha of the Devanagari script, gives it an Indian identity. Seen along with the second horizontal line, it represents the three bands of the tricolour of our Indian flag.

text: ACTIVITY 19.3: SIMILAR BUT DIFFERENT

subject: ARTS
text: Observe the table below. It shows different versions of the same letter.

subject: ARTS
text: Are you able to read the same letter written in so many ways?

subject: ARTS
text: This is similar to human or animal bodies. We have the same body parts, yet we look unique. Human anatomy is about the number of bones, muscles, joints, etc. Similarly, the anatomy of letters reveals the different parts of a letter.

subject: ARTS
text: D

subject: ARTS
text: Step 1: Choose a letter from any script you are familiar with.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 2: Take a sheet of paper and write the letter you have chosen in different ways.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 3: Start by writing letters freely. Use your non-dominant hand, and see the lines and shapes that are formed. Use different kinds of pens, pencils and other writing tools. Make the letters big and small.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 4: Take another sheet of paper. To structure the same letter, mark a baseline, top line and a middle line.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 5: Mark vertical lines to create a grid. This will help you estimate the width of each alphabet, as well as the space between each letter.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 6: Create five variations of the same letter. Use the guidelines to alter the height, width, angles and line-thickness of the letters to achieve different styles. Begin writing the letter, keeping in mind its anatomy.

subject: ARTS
text: Step 7: Share your work with your peers. Discuss how you wrote one letter in different ways.

subject: ARTS
text: ACTIVITY 19.4: WRITING LIKE WE SPEAK

subject: ARTS
text: When you speak to people, you modulate your voice which creates a variation in the volume. Doing this conveys various emotions. For example, when you wish your friend “Happy Birthday!” you say it with excitement and joy, whereas when you say, “Get well soon”, you say it calmly and show concern.

subject: ARTS
text: If we relate it to writing, it could be that a loud voice is written in big, bold letters, whereas softer voice is written in small letters.

subject: ARTS
text: Now, why don’t you try to shape letters in a variety of ways to convey the meanings and emotions of words?

subject: ARTS
text: Look at the examples on the right side and try creating your own in a language or script that you are comfortable with.

text: Art is a powerful language that speaks to your mind and heart. What you feel and experience during a concert or while viewing a painting is something that cannot be put in words. subject: ARTS
text: Outcome

subject: ARTS
text: This activity helps students connect with India’s rich heritage of temple art while encouraging teamwork, storytelling and creativity. By integrating music, movement and dialogue, they learn to bring history to life in an engaging and imaginative way.
